statement.tex: \text{Examine the continuty of the function}\\ f(x) = \vert x-5 \vert

step.context: \text{which of the following correctly defines f(x)? }\\

step.tex: f(x) \text{ is a straight line for }x\neq 5.\\ \text{Hence, it is continuous for all }x\neq 5.\\ \text{But we need to check for continuity at }x=5.
step.reason: \text{At }x=5\text{, the definition of the function}\\ \text{changes. Hence, x = 5 could be the only}\\ \text{problem point. We should check for}\\ \text{continuity there.}

step.tex:
\lim_{x\to 5^-}f(x) = \lim_{x\to 5^-} (5-x) = 0 \\ \lim_{x\to 5^+}f(x) = \lim_{x\to 5^+} (x-5) = 0 \\ f(5) = \vert 5-5 \vert = 0
\\ \text{Hence, f(x) is also continuous at x=5.}\\
step.reason: \text{In Step 2, we established that f(x) is }\\ \text{continuous at }x\neq 5. \text{Now, we have proven}\\ \text{continuity at x=5. Hence, f(x) is continuous}\\ \text{for all x.}

choices.tex: \text{Continuous at just x=5 and discontinuous\\ everywhere in it's domain}
\text{Discontinuous at just x=5 and continuous\\ everywhere in it's domain}
